DIV1.P: As it is Acted At the Theatre Royal in Drury-Lane, By His MAJESTIES Servants.
Son of the late Earl RIVERS.
DIV1.L: LOVE, studious how to Please, improves our Parts,

L.HI: With polish'd Manners, and adorns with Arts.

DIV1.P: LONDON: Printed for E. CURLL, at the Dial and Bible; and R. FRANCKLIN, at the Sun, both against St. Dun∣stan's Church in Fleet-street; and W. CHETWOOD, at Cato's Head in Russel-Court near the Theatre Royal. MDCCXIX.

DIV1.HEAD: TO THE Right Honourable GEORGE Lord LANSDOWN.
DIV1.P:
AN Address from a Stran∣ger, and one that asks Favours too, ought to have more Recom∣mendation then I am afraid you will find in this. It is my Misfortune to stand in such a Relation to the late Earl RIVERS, by the Countess of—, as neither of us can
be proud of Owning; but that is the smallest part of my Unhappiness, since I am one of those Sons of Sorrow, to whom he left nothing, to alleviate the Sin of my Birth. Under this Scene of Affliction, I have had Lei∣sure enough to divert my Hours of Melancholly with Writing this CO∣MEDY, for which I humbly beg Your Lordship's Patronage. My Play, and my Self, my Lord, are equally Orphans, and in that View only, I desire your Lordship would look upon

LG.L: THE Youthful Author of our Scenes to Day;
Who scarce writes Man, has boldly writ a Play!
But now we fear New Plays no more can thrive,
Than Summer Fruits in Winter Frosts survive.
Poetick Lawrels then triumphant show,
And shall their Branches now less chearful Grow?
Shall those kind genial Heats that Bless the Year,
Come to create a Barren Season here?
Or, shall that Tree, Fame's Wreath by PHOEBUS made,
Now Parch! and at his sultry Influence Fade?
Our Poet, who to Night attempts at Praise,
From various Turns, wou'd your Diversion raise.
To please Gay Fancies, he at Humour strove,
At Plot for Criticks, for the Ladies Love.
Yet Life's low Scenes he owns may here seem scarce,
But well-wrought Business makes amends for Farce.
Not but our Scene drawn on a Foreign Coast
Of homebred Fools might some resemblance boast;
For tho' each Clime t'improve the Muses Toil,
Yet Fools, like Weeds; shoot up in every Soil.
Our lively Images are too sublime!
We draw our Glory from the British-Clime.
In our wild Hero's Character we tell,
What Love, what Honour in the English dwell.
Not one of Nature's Monsters here we show,
Yet thro' our Scenes some seeds of Satire strow.
Be gen'rous then! And let our Author's Care,
Appease the Criticks, and Divert the Fair.

ROW.CELL: Lorenzo, Governour of Va∣lencia, Father to Leonora.
Sir Charles Winlove, An English Gentleman, fled from Ma∣drid for the Death of his Rival.
Don Philip, A Noble Spaniard, Contracted to Leonora.
Aspin, Servant to Sir Ch. Winlove
Fidelia, A youngLady fled after Sir Charles Winlove to Valencia.

DIV1.HEAD: LOVE in a VEIL. A COMEDY.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, I. The STREET.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter, Sir CHARLES WINLOVE, and DON PHILIP, meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: DON Philip!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Sir Charles Winlove! What Miracle has brought you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Why faith, 'tis a Miracle owing to Fortune—Have you heard what has happen'd to me at Madrid?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: I heard of your unfortunate Adven∣ture there, before I left it—How long have you been come to Valencia?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: About a Fortnight, and I only wait for a fair Wind to carry me to England.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: I'de advise you to make the best of your Way, for there was a Rumour that Orders wou'd be sent to the Sea-Ports to put a Stop to your Passage.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Why this comes now of Intriguing in Spain—A Man can't carry on an Amour, but he must cut the Throat of some jealous Coxcomb or other to Cure him of his Impertinence—But what other News? I find you left Madrid la∣ter than I did—Is my Rival that I Wounded, Dead?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: When I came away I heard that his Life was despair'd of.—And that the Lady for whom your Quarrel began, was fled from her Fa∣ther's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: I am sorry for her sake, for She is every way so Agreeable; that cou'd I learn to be Con∣stant, twou'd be only to her—But I find one Love is still an Antidote to Expel another: For I have seen such a Beauty here in Valencia.—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Another Beauty, Sir Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Aye, one so Charming, so good Hu∣mour'd, and so Witty, she's enough to turn the Resolutions of a Cynick—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Is She a Woman of Quality?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Faith, I can't tell—Her Appearance is as yet like that f Cynthia in a Cloud, for I have never seen her but in a VEIL.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: I thought to have heard that you'd have been more Cautious Sir Charles—But I find you are still the same, and are resolv'd to bear the Frowns of Fortune, with as much Pleasure as her Smiles—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P:
Aye, Don Philip, Let Cowards fear her, and Fools her daily Favourites Adore her—For my Part, Love and Friendship shall still be the Darlings of my Soul—And new Pleasures,
the continual Business of my Life—But prithee what sort of Company have you here in Valen∣cia—For tho' I am Returning to England, I am so tir'd with Politicks, that I perfectly Nauseate the Conversation of it.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: How so? Is there no other to be had then—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: None! Politicians start out of every Profession, and Stock-jobbers-Lies, are the only Discourse one can meet with.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: I hope the Beaus don't turn Politici∣ans in any Nation—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: The Beaus! Why the very Women are turn'd Politicians—In short, the Gossiping of the Tea-Table is as much Infected, as the Society of the Coffee-Houses—How are you at this Part of the Globe?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: We are like the rest of the World.—Here are all Manner of Characters—Husbands that are Jealous of their Honour, and Wives that as Craftily betray it—For the Ladies—Here's a Composition of all Nations—Some boast the Affectation of the French; some their own natu∣ral Spanish Pride; and others the Beauty and Ob∣stinacy of your English Women—Then for the Men, here are from the formal Grandees, to the extravagant Fops; and from the Cavaliers of Qua∣lity, to the very Fortune-Hunters—In short, here are all Degrees whatsoever—Some of 'em rely upon the Merit of their Riches, and others upon that of their Assurance—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Assurance is the most thriving Vertue of the Age. 'Tis a Fortune for a Courtier; and a prevailing Eloquence in a Lover—But a∣mongst the rest, What sort of a Man is your Go∣vernour?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: A Man of Quality, and one whose in∣nate Worth, is an Honour to the Office he bears—Now I think on't, he may be of Service to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Aye, prithee which way?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: He has a Daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Is she very Handsome?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Beautiful as an Angel, and then for her Wit, 'tis as Inchanting, as her Beauty, her Repartees are as Quick as her Eyes, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: And when shall I see her Don Philip?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: She's to be my Wife—For which purpose I am come here to Valencia.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: How coud'st thou be so Ill-natur'd now, to raise my fancy to such a Pitch for this? What Service can it be to me.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: I did not design to help you to a Mi∣stress Sir Charles, I only had a Mind to let you know my Interest with the Governour, and I hope to win him to Intercede for your Pardon, and to wink at your Security here.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Oh! you are ever Obliging Don Philip.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: This is a Trifle amongst Friends—I remember in England, when I was Oppress'd by odds, you sav'd my Life with hazard of your own—Here I run no Risque in the Preservati∣on of yours—But how d'ye intend to spend the Day?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: I have an Assignation, but the Time is not yet expir'd.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: In the mean Time what say you to a Glass of good Wine?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: With all my Heart—For 'tis still my Opinion, that next to the Chat of a Lady at her Tea-Table, there's no Pleasure like the Society of a Friend over a Bottle.—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Oh you are ever pleasant Sir Charles.—But ha! Who comes here?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: 'Tis my Servant!—Don Philip, you'll excuse me a little, I'll be with you immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: I see you are upon the Scent of an In∣trigue! Well, I won't interrupt you, when you've done with your Emissary—Follow me to the next Inn, where I'll wait for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Do so, I'll talk but a Minute with my Man, and then I am your's over a Bottle.
So Aspin, What News have you brought me of the Lady in the VEIL?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: News! Sir, if I had accomplish'd my Ends, I cou'd have brought you News and Success enough to make your Heart leap up to your Mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Look ye Sirrah don't trifle, my Time's too precious, by repeating what you only fancy you cou'd have done; but tell me what Success you have had in Reality.—Did you dog the Lady as I order'd you?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Dog the Lady! Aye Sir, I have dog'd her to some Purpose! Well, I'll say no more, but if Expedition and Conduct can make a Statesman, Aspin may in time come to be distinguish'd by a Title.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Nay, I can scarce doubt of your Suc∣cess, for I know thou art an excellent Setter up∣on Occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Aye, and a Runner too, as you'll find by the Sequel of the Story—Look ye Sir, you may remember you order'd me to Watch the La∣dy Home, I obey'd your Commands, but She perceiving my Employment, led me thro' the Mazes of several blind Alleys; notwithstanding which, like an experienc'd Instrument of the Game, I still kept as close a Scent after her, as a Hound after her Coney.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: A very pretty Similitude!—But have you Hous'd her? Tell me that Part of the Story Aspin!

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Hous'd her! No Sir, I han't Hous'd her!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: No Sirrah! Then what's the End of all this mighty Performance?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Nothing at all Sir!—In short, there fell out an unlucky Accident, for as I was hot in the Pursuit, I happen'd to stumble upon a Pebble, sprain'd my Ancle, and lost the Sight of her in a Moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Now Sirrah, wou'd I break your Bones for this Disappointment, but that I have other Affairs in Hand—Mark me, I am now going to Drink a Bottle with a Friend, in an Hour I am to meet the Lady at my Lodging; and if you don't look better to your Post, I'll break that Rascally Head of yours Sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Aye to be sure! What damnable Lives do we poor Servants lead! if we Succeed in the most difficult Adventure, we do but our Duty forsooth, but if we fail; I ll break your Head you Rascal, hold, let me think how shall I retrieve my Misfortunes.

Ha! As I live, here's Sir Charles Winlove's Man! Now, if I could learn where he is by this Fellow, I would immediately give an Information against him to my Lord Governour! but no doubt my young Lady's with him, Soft, he does not know me, therefore I'll accost him and try [comes for∣ward.] Hist! Friend do you live hereabouts?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp
SP.P: Humph! ha! Why what is that to you Friend where I Live? I owe you nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Dieg.
SP.P: But I owe you a great deal.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Say you so Sir! Come pay then, pay, Egad this Fellow has mistaken me for some Body else; now if I should luckily come in for a round Sum that I have no pretence to, faith 'twould be very welcome—But as you was saying Sir, what do you owe me?

SP.SPEAKER: Dieg.
SP.P: A great deal of Respect Sir, as you are a fine Gentlemen, and all that Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Pho' Pox d'ye mean to banter me? If that's all, I won't give a Pin for your Debt Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dieg.
SP.P: Oh! But Sir! You don't comprehend me, my Respect is but the prelude to something Greater.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Ha! To something Greater! Egad this Fellow has the Air of what we call in down∣right English a Pimp, Odso! Aspin thou art a made Man!

SP.SPEAKER: Dieg.
SP.P: The Fellow seems tickled with some Ima∣gination, that may be of use to me, I'll study to improve it [Aside.] But as I was saying Sir, may not I be so happy to know your Lodging—Come, don't stand in your own Light, I'll engage you shall be handsomly Rewarded by one greater than my self.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Egad it is so—Some Seniora has fix'd her Affections upon me; what is she Sir, what is she?—Harkee which part of me has tickled her Ladyship's Fancy, Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Dieg.
SP.P: As I guess'd; I'll Humour him—I am under an Obligation not to—

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Not to—What? Come, come, hang Secrecy! Is it the Broadness of my Shoulders? The Big∣ness of my Calves? Or the Air of my Gate?—That has done it? Ha? Odso, now I think on't, I warrant the Jade has heard I am an Irishman—Aye, there it is Faith now.

SP.SPEAKER: Dieg.
SP.P: Aye, Aye, you have hit it! Therefore if you'll let me see where you Lodge, I'll bring a Chair for you in the Evening, and Convey you to the Arms of the most Beautiful Madona in all Valencia.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Aye! But upon second Thoughts! I find I am very Unfit for such an Adventure.

SP.SPEAKER: Dieg.
SP.P: What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Mean! Why I mean that I ever had from my Cradle, a damnable Aversion to a Pistol or a Poniard—Nay, now I think on't, last Night I had an ugly Dream about the Noise of a Pistol—But hang Dreams, they shall never fright a Man of my Courage—Know then, Sir, I live at yon∣der Green-Rails, I am but a Valet or so Sir, but in an Hour I shall be at the Lady's Command—In the mean time I'll follow the Example of my Master, and drink a Bottle to prepare my self for her Service.

SP.SPEAKER: Dieg.
SP.P: This Fool has betray'd his Master as I cou'd Wish—But now for my Lord Governour.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, The Governour's House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lorenzo with a Letter, and Diego.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Bring you this from Madrid say you?—But hold, let me peruse it.

LETTER.P: AN English Cavalier, who has lately kill'd a Nobleman of Spain; is fled away with my Daughter; and as I am inform'd, they have taken their way to Valencia—I desire you will loose no time in endeavouring to Seize 'em—The Bearer will give you a full Description of both.

SP.P: From Madrid.
I take it kindly that my Friend remembers me in this Misfortune—For I owe him many Ob∣ligations—Who is this Cavalier?

SP.SPEAKER: Dieg.
SP.P: He is call'd Sir Charles Winlove, and he un∣doubtedly Stole her, for she was the Cause of their Duel.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Where do you think he is?

SP.SPEAKER: Dieg.
SP.P: My Lord, I had just now Notice of his Lodging from his own Servant, and if you please I'll prepare Officers in order to Seize him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P:
Do so, and I'll go in Person! [Exit Diego] Un∣fortunate
Alonzo! how unhappy is the Man, the Honour of whose Family depends on a Woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: What makes you so Thoughtful, Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: If you knew the Contents of this Paper, Leonora, you wou'd not wonder that the Cares of a Father shou'd make me Thoughtful.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Why so my Lord? I hope I have not been Guilty of any thing to displease you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Not as yet—But the Duty of a Parent is a great Weight, and where the Loss of Honour depends; 'tis to be fear'd, more than the loss of Life—I am in hast at present, and must de∣fer this Subject till another Opportunity—In the mean time take heed my Leonora.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I am Confus'd—What does my Fa∣ther mean by the Loss of Honour.?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: I am afraid Madam, that he knows some of your Haunts, and therefore I'd advise you to be Cautious.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: 'Tis hard that a Spanish Woman can't have an Amour, but some jealous pated Father, or Brother must interfere with the Honour of his Fa∣mily: Now I have heard, that the English Women may take what Diversion they please, and be ra∣ther Celebrated for their Beauty, than Censur'd.—Nay, that the very Wives may have a whole Equipage of Lovers, and be the more admir'd by their Husbands.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P:
'Tis the Nature of the Climate, Madam, as in France the Coquet is rather Admired for her Airs, then Censur'd for her Inclinations. Not but there's detraction in both Climates, but there 'tis a pleasure peculiar to the Women, where
Scandal passes for Wit, and one Beauty rises on the falling Reputation of another. The Men un∣less the Beaus, having nothing to do with it; and those no farther, then a little Raillery for their Diversion.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I cou'd be as free as they had I the Power—For I have chose a Person of my own Liking, and my Father has Contracted me to one that is indifferent to me. Now methinks there's such a pleasure in the Disobedience, that it adds an Elo∣quence to the Suit of a Lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: But Madam, d'ye Consider that the Nature of this Country is Revenge—Here is none of the Careless Brother, the Indulgent Father, nor the meek Animal, a Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: 'Tis want of Courage in our Lovers to put a good Custom in practice, otherwise the Jealous fury of a Spanish Don might in time be moderated to the Content of a London Citizen.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: But Madam, you have not so much reason to Complain—Is not Don Philip, your intend∣ed Husband, a Noble Spaniard, and as Agreeable as the English Cavalier.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Oh what a hideous Comparison have you made! the English Cavalier! Is he not all that a Woman can wish for? A Man of Gallantry—Beautiful in his Person, and agreeable in his Con∣versation? are not all the Perswasive Charms of Wit upon his Tongue? Is he not in short, an Englishman.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Is not Don Philip a Man of Honour? of a Gallant Disposition—And then he loves you as well as the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P:
Aye, but then he is to be my Husband, Flora; and the Prospect of a forc'd Marriage E∣clipses the Worth of a Suitor—Besides my Mo∣ther was an English Woman—Therefore I am of so Gay a Temper, and so naturally Fond of Li∣berty,
that I can never be confin'd to the Hu∣mours of a jealous Spaniard.—

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: I am convinc'd, Madam, by your Incli∣nations to the English Cavalier; that Beauty is totally owing to Fancy—But how came you Acquainted with him at first?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I'll tell you—You know when my Fa∣ther sent for me to Valencia, the People after my Arrival crowded to see me—I was admir'd by the Men, and envy'd by the Women—When I appear'd at Church, all were in a Consternation—Whispering, this is the Governour's Daughter—Till contrary to my Sex, I was almost tir'd with Vanity itself—One Day I went VEIL'D into the Walks to Divert my self—There I thought I saw my Father, but afterwards it prov'd otherwise—Then I flew into a Summer House to avoid him—Where I met this Stranger, who seeing me in Distress, proffer'd his Assistance—I was pleas'd with the Complement, and lik'd both his Conversation and his Person—He press'd to know me, but I refus'd it—How∣ever, I have often seen him since, and must in short according to Appointment, meet him instant∣ly agen.—

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: But Madam, your Father has agreed for your Marriage, and this Appartment has receiv'd your intended Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: A Lady desires to see you, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Who is She?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: I never saw her before.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Desire her to Walk in.—

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Madam, I am come, tho' unknown, an humble Petitioner to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: If 'tis a Secret, I'll hear it alone, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: No, 'tis what a Servant must know, if Granted.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: In what can I Serve you?

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: In giving Refuge to an unfortunate Per∣son—But e're I tell you my Story, be pleas'd to Peruse that Letter.—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Madam, you are Welcome upon the Re∣commendation of Theodosia—I hope she's well.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: I thank you Madam, she's very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: You shall be us'd with as much Respect as my self—She has here Inform'd me, you're Unfortunate, but the Particulars I am Ignorant of.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: That Task is left for me—Which I shall tell you in a few Words—I am the Daughter of a Nobleman, whose Name in Re∣spect to him, I Conceal—I Lov'd unknown to him, an English Cavalier—For whom as I was Waiting one Night at the Garden Gate, a∣nother whom I slighted rush'd in with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I fear the Consequence was fatal Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: It was indeed—He whom I had the least Affection for, Exasperated by Jealousy and Revenge, immediately drew—They fought, he fell! Whereupon the English Gentleman present∣ly took Horse and rode away.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: What Course cou'd you take in this Ex∣tremity of Fortune?

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P:
Alass Madam, I was so frighned, I knew not what I did—I Shriek'd and Cry'd for help when 'twas too late—Thereupon, a Tumult
arose—My Father call'd for me! instead of Answering him, I fled from his Anger, and Theo∣dosia conceal'd me till I came here—The un∣happy Gentleman that was Vanquish'd, Liv'd to tell who Kill'd him, and the Cause, and by this time I believe is Expir'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I am sorry for your Misfortunes, and will endeavour to Moderate 'em—I know my self what 'tis to Love against a Father's Will—Therefore depend on my Assistance.—

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Madam, I thank you, that's all that's in my Power.—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: No more Ceremonies—You are Theo∣dosia's Representative of Friendship, and as such I Esteem you—Flora, shew the Lady in, and order Clara to Attend her, I wou'd not have my Father see you, till he has giv'n leave to receive you.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Methinks I am touch'd for her Misfor∣tunes—As if my own—Besides, who knows what the Consequences of my Love may prove.—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: My VEIL, Flora, I'll meet this Cava∣lier instantly.—

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Madam, beware of a Discovery by so of∣ten venturing.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Too much Caution, is no good Conduct in an Amour; for Lovers have a thousand Ar∣tifices in the worst of Dangers.

Q.L: In Love and War, we must no Fears betray;
Valour's the Conduct, that must win the Day.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: 'T WAS Excellent Wine; and me-thinks my Mistresses Health has so Elevated my Fancy, that it has inspir'd me for the Assignation—Let me see, 'tis just upon the time of the Apointment—Where have you been Sirrah?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Drinking the Lady's Health, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: You are a pretty Fellow to Toast that indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Sir, I guess'd you were at the same Sport, and that made me follow the Example.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Sirrah, the Airs of my Conversation as ill become one of your Character, as those of my Dress; but like the Vulgar in a factious Coun∣try, you Love to Ape the Actions of your Superiors.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Sir, a Valet, Claims as great a Title to his Master's Second-hand Wit, as to his Cast off Cloaths, and Custom has equally made 'em the due Perquisites of his Place.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Retire Quickly—The Lady's Com∣ing.

Q.L: Thus Sol, when he his Amber Beauty Shrouds;

L.HI: Revives the Flowers, tho' wrapt like you, in Clouds.
In Beams that stray some cheerful Influence Steals,
Till the kind God at length his Rays reveals.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: That's more than I may Chance to do, if you are so Complaisant, as to mean me by the Comparison.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: That you may Chance to do! I am very glad Madam, that you are so Dubious as to leave it to Chance. 'Tis possible you may Chance to be Cruel, but I hope that the Proba∣bility is to the contrary.—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: The probability depends indeed upon your Hope—And Lovers Hopes are at best but Shadows of Thought, that produce no Reality.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Madam, you are pleas'd to be Witty, and I admire you for it—But the Sight of you wou'd make me your perfect Adorer.—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: D'ye think there's no true Love without seeing the Object.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: No certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: How d'ye think a blind Man can be sen∣sible of the Passion, if he did not depend on his Imagination. Now perhaps were you to see me, you'd no longer Admire me, therefore, I think you had best remain as you are.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Hold, I forbid that Madam—A blind Man can never hope to see the Object of his Af∣fections, and therefore can never expect to satis∣fie his Curiosity—But Sight was given me to make use of—And shou'd I be so Contented, I shou'd suffer you to Blind my Reason, as well as my Eyes.—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Can you be a Lover, and pretend to the use of Reason—That's a Contradiction in itself.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Not in the least—'Tis a ranging un∣settled Passion that's a Contradiction to good Sense—But Love and Reason are Inseparable like Wit and Judgment—For as one is fond of the Beauty, the other distinguishes the Value of the Blessing, and therefore knows how to Prize it.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Notwithstanding your Rhetorick, they are an Objection to each other—For according to the Dictates of Love, I ought to grant your De∣sires, and let you see me—But shou'd I now follow the Maxims of Reason, I shou'd remain in a Cloud as I am—And here break off our Correspondence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: That I deny—For as Love has Prompted you thus far, Reason will shew you 'tis too late now to retire, therefore you see that every Argument you raise, is an Objection to your Cruelty—Besides, when we parted last, You promised I should see You—And I hope You will be as good as your Word now.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: But you know the Promises of Ladies, Lo∣vers, and Courtiers are seldom of any Effect—However I won't stand with you for a Trifle—How d'ye like me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: I am considering with my Self, whe∣ther you are an Angel or a Woman—I thought so much Wit cou'd not be obscur'd in a common Form—And now I stand Convinc'd in Admi∣ration. [Noise] Hey! What's the matter now?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Fly Sir, Fly immediately for your Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Fly! prithee for what Reason?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: We shall only be hang'd Sir, that's all, if we stay—But I ll secure the Garden-Door to favour our Retreat, if there's any to be made.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: What's the matter Fellow, are you Mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Mad? No, 'tis my Master is Mad to stay here—Leap over the Wall—Fly any way Sir, for here's the Governour with a whole Troop of Jacks in Office at his Heels come to Seize you.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Alass my Father, Flora! undoubtedly he's come thus on my Account.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Sure no Man is so Unfortunate!—Can Love never come, but attended with Crosses and Disappointments?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Dear Sir, don't talk of Love now—Consider we are in danger of a Halter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Force open the Doors there.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Sir, What d'ye mean? Love is always the fore-runner of Mischief—A Pox on it, our Misfortune came from Love before.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Sir, I am ruin'd if the Governour sees me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Fair Lady, I must leave you, my Life depends on it.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: And my Honour—Hold, Can you be so barbarous to leave me here?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Can you be so barbarous to make us stay here, if you go to that.
Sir, make haste, or we shall be too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Stay! I am greater than you think—'Tis for me they Come—And can you leave a Woman in Distress? think you my Honour's no∣thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Nothing at all to Compare with our Lives—
Sir, Are you Mad, don't you hear?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: 'Twas ungenerous in me to leave Fide∣lia in Danger—They shan't say I always serve a Woman so—Madam, my Life shall Answer for your Defence—Go into that Arbour whilst I Guard the Door.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Nay, Since you are resolved to be taken Sir, I'll not keep you Company.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Come down you Pidgeon-hearted Ras∣cal, and learn to stand to a noble Defence.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Sir, Conduct is more requir'd than Cou∣rage—Therefore to run away will be the no∣blest Defence, because 'tis the Wisest.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: So! Now they come! the Door is fal∣ling from it's Hinges.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Are not you Sir Charles Winlove, an English Cavalier?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: I scorn to deny my Name.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Seize him! now to Prison with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Sir, Consider, I'm no common Per∣son.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I know you are a Man of Quality, and as such I shall use you. Restore the Gentleman his Sword—Where's the Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: The Lady say you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Aye, the Lady Sir Charles.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: A Lady with me! What d'ye mean my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: You need not deny it, I come well In∣form'd. Search about there.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: What Woman can it be, that has brought me into this Misfortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: What Fellow's that.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: A Servant of mine my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Secure him.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Now Sir, Had not leaping over the Wall, and making to Sea, been a much better Journey than a Ride to the Gallows—We had better have run the risque of being pickled in Salt Wa∣ter, than of Hanging like a couple of Signs, be∣tween Earth and Air; You for a Warning to all Resolute Lovers, and I to such Servants as follow their Masters desperate Fortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: What Glove's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Alg.
SP.P: 'Tis a Lady's.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Then 'tis probable She can't be far off—Search that Arbour.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I am half Dead with Confusion—'Tis my Father, what can I expect?

SP.SPEAKER: Alg.
SP.P: In a Corner of the Arbour we found this Lady—Unveil to my Lord Governor.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Madam, you need not, for I know you well.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: What does he say? Was ever Woman so Unfortunate?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I am sensible what Courtesy I owe you—Pardon the Nature of my coming for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: And pardon me that she does not go with you—For single as I am, and thus Op∣press'd by odds, I had rather dye, then she shou'd be a Sufferer.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Generous Cavalier.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Is this the honourable Use you make of the Restoration of your Sword—but you shall find we can Quell you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: I tell you Lord, I know to Oppose you is to Die, and that I can with pleasure in Vin∣dication of distress'd Innocence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Don't think to deceive me! I know you both—Her Father's so much my Friend, I am equally Concern'd with him for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: These Words Confirm my Fears! what shall I think or say.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Use her well my Lord, that's all I ask.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: My Honour on her Usage.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Nay, If our General comes to a Parley, a Surrender follows of Course—Sir, my Courage is rais'd at last, and so let us e'en Fight it out with 'em now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: My Lord, I rely on your Honour, and Submit.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Then I am Lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Keep your Sword still—Here, take this Gentleman to the Castle—For the Lady, she shall be in my House, and receiv'd there as my Daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: As his Daughter! I see now I am cer∣tainly discover'd—

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Bring that Fellow along—He shall go with his Master—Hark you, a Word with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Now when I am in the humour of Fight∣ing, 'tis very hard to be giv'n up a Prisoner, and have my Valour nipt in the Bud.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Madam, don't be Dejected—Our next Meeting may be a turn of Joy—And I hope this Adventure in the End, will but prove like a little Discord in Musick, which raises it to a sweeter Harmony.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Come, 'tis time for you now to Part—Mr. Alguazile, dispose of the Lady as I order'd you—Lead on there.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: So! they are gone! I overheard all, and 'twas lucky they did not see me in the opposite Corner to my Lady—What Woman wou'd trust an Assignation, if this was always to be the Consequence—But I must run Home the back Ways, and prepare the Family for her Recepti∣on.—

SP.SPEAKER: Don Phil.
SP.P: What! no body to be found! Me∣thinks the House looks as if the Family had De∣serted it—Where can they all be gone?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: So! thanks to my Stars, I have got Home before 'em—But I have run till I am quite out of Breath [Starts.] Don Philip!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Flora, where are all the Family?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: My Lady is gone Abroad.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Where's my Lord Governour?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: He has just now sent an English Cavalier Prisoner to the Castle.—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Ha! an English Cavalier! d'ye know who he is?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: One Sir Charles Winlove, my Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Flora, That Cavalier is my dearest Friend—But wherefore do I loiter—I'll fly this Moment to meet the Governour, and try to Intercede in his Behalf.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: There's one Obstacle remov'd—But here they come.

SP.SPEAKER: Alg.
SP.P: Where's the Lady Leonora? I have a Mes∣sage to her from the Governour.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: What does the Fellow mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: There's certainly some Mistake in this—I'll humour it [Aside] Perhaps it may prove a lucky Turn. The Lady Leonora Friend, is Abroad—And therefore you may leave your Message.—

SP.SPEAKER: Alg.
SP.P: My Lord Governour has sent this Person a Prisoner—But Orders that your Lady will take care to have her us'd Respectfully—So here my Commission Ends, and I leave her to your Charge.—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Are they gone?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Yes.—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I was never so frighned in my Life—What Excuse shall I make to my Father: Certainly, he knew me by what he said—And his Cauti∣on to me this Morning confirms it.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: I rather believe Madam, he mistook you for another; and by all Circumstances for the Lady you receiv'd to Day.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Ha! I have a Thought—She said she look'd for an English Cavalier that has kill'd a Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: And Madam, by the Circumstance of flying from her Father's House, my Lord Govern∣our may think he has Seiz'd 'em together.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: If so, I have a Rival.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: If so, you'll come clear off, by turning it upon her; I'll take away your VEIL, that you mayn't seem as if you had been Abroad.—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Thou'rt a perfect Machiavil Flora—I cou'd no more Part with thee, than I cou'd with my better Genius.—

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: A good Servant is as great a Jewel as a good Husband Madam—And if you play your Cards to the best Advantage, 'tis not in the Power of Fortune to Pique you.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: But shou'd I serve the Lady so now I have receiv'd her, 'twill be a breach of Friendship and Hospitality.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P:
Great Statesmen always Sacrifice their Friendship to their Interest—Besides, Self-Preservation
is the first Law of Nature, and if you neglect this Opportunity, you are Ruin'd for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: But still methinks I have some Scruples of Honour, Flora.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: A Lady's Honour Madam, consists in her Reputation; and if you persist, you'll Sacrifice that to the Censure of the World, and be oblig'd like her you have receiv'd, to fly from your Fa∣ther's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Well, thou art an Excellent Casuist for the Scruples of a tender Conscience—But if we shou'd be mistaken in the Lady now.—

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Never fear Madam—I heard my Lord Governour call the English Cavalier by the Title of Sir Charles Winlove—Therefore, for better Sa∣tisfaction, ask her the Name of her Lover—Oh, here she comes opportunely to our Purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I'll sift her by Degrees that She mayn't suspect me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Have you prest my Suit to the Govern∣our yet Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I have not as yet had an Opportunity, but I expect him every Minute to come Home, and then you may depend on't, I'll use all my Interest to serve you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: I see Madam, you answer the Character I have had of you—For you differ from the La∣dies of Fashion, who instead of pitying our Sex in Misfortunes, are the first that reflect on 'em and expose 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: None of our Sex are so ungenerous, but such who being Guilty themselves, wou'd endea∣vour to hide their own Frailties, by censuring the Conduct of others.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: I esteem it as the greatest Happiness, that I have met with such a comfortable Refuge in the midst of my Misfortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I am always Madam, apt rather to assist a Lady in Distress, than to Reflect on her—But shou'd the Governor comply with my Request, What farther Courses do you design to take?

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: I'll search out for the English Cavalier; who I am inform'd is here in Valencia—Otherwise if I shou'd miss of him, I hear my Friends are en∣deavouring to make my Peace with my Father, and as he was ever Fond of me, I hope his Tender∣ness will overcome his Passion, and that he'll a∣gain receive me as his Child.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I hope all will turn to your Advantage Madam—But in the mean time, what's the Gentleman's Name, whom you are in search of?—Perhaps I may learn where he is, if he's in Valencia.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: His Name is Sir Charles Winlove.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Sir Charles Winlove say you! this increases my Misfortunes—Have I foster'd a Rival?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Keep your Temper Madam, and stick to what you propos'd, We'll find an After-Plot to redeem all.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: She changes Colour, what can this mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Now you may return to Madrid, and in∣form Alonzo that his Daughter's secur'd in my House, and Sir Charles Winlove in the Castle.

SP.SPEAKER: Dieg.
SP.P: But my Lord, I han't seen her yet, and therefore can't affirm it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I'll call her then.

SP.SPEAKER: Dieg.
SP.P: I shou'd rather be glad to see her, so that she might not see me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Hold, there's my Daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Dieg.
SP.P: and with her my Lady—For she on her left Hand is Fidelia.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Now can you return with Confidence?

SP.SPEAKER: Dieg.
SP.P: I can my Lord, farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: My Father Approaches!

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: I'll retire Madam, while you press my Suit to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: What makes the Lady shun me Leonora.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Because She's a Stranger, and that makes her a little reserv'd my Lord,

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: D'ye Remember my Advice this Morning Daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Now my Fears!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Now Leonora, you may see the Effect of making private Assignatious unknown to a Father—And of exposing a Reputation, and the Hon∣our of a Family—What d'ye think will be the Consequence of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Of what my Lord? I am discover'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Recollect the adventures of this Morning, and then you may Guess at my meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I see my Stratagems are in Vain—My Lord, too well I understand you—And therefore throw me at your Feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: She has discover'd all, what shall we do now?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: What do you mean? Are you at cross Pur∣poses Child?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: My Lord, I beg you hear me, and perhaps I may give you Satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Rise then, and if you intend to give me Satisfaction, Let it be in a reasonable Answer—What makes you in this Confusion?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: My Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Are you so touch'd with yonder Lady's Misfortunes, that you can kneel in her behalf?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Ha, I am amaz'd! what an unexpected Turn is here.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: The Governour fixes his Eyes on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I am glad you are so good Natur'd, Leo∣nora! for tho' that Lady is a Prisoner, she is the Daughter of my dearest Friend, and therefore I'de have her us'd with singular Respect.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Am I in my Senses? or do I Dream?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Courage Madam, all's well agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I had like to have betray'd my self by my timorous Folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: The Governour Approaches—I hope She has succeeded.—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Ha! here comes another Turn of Disco∣very.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Madam, you are welcome to my House—I know your Quality, and am sorry for this Ac∣cident.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: My Lord I thank you—You see me here a Stranger in this Place—Therefore to raise your Pity to my Misfortunes, give me leave to relate their Particulars.—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Ha! if she Talks, she betrays all—And then we shall be entirely Undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I know your Story already Madam—Our Histories are full of such amorous Adventures—But I question not, but your's will shortly have a happy End—In the mean time, this House shall rather be your Sanctuary than Confine∣ment—Daughter, I recommend this Lady to your Conversation.—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Excellently come off.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: I find Madam by my Success, that you have pleaded strongly in my Behalf.—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I ev'n Kneel'd to my Father to serve you, and am glad that it has lain in my Power.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: I thank you Madam—I shall never for∣get such Obligations—You'll excuse me for retiring, for I am Impatient till I have writ an Account of my Success to Theodosia.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: It goes according to our Wish—My Fa∣ther supposes 'twas her he Seiz'd with Sir Charles, and she knows nothing of her being a Prisoner; but is pleas'd with her Confinement.—

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: The end must Crown all Madam—And if you can carry on the Mistake—'Twill be excellent indeed! but how d'ye intend to Pro∣ceed?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Suppose I write to Sir Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Consider Madam, what you do.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: You are the first Servant, that ever was against a Lover—You see we are come well off—In Love as in Gaming, if we can make a shift to save our selves, the hopes of winning is a Temptation to Play on.—

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: But Madam, a little luck is commonly a Rook, that draws young Gamesters in to their Destruction.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: A lucky Cast is seldom won by a faint Heart—Love is a Lottery, and therefore.—

Q.L: As Ventures only, can our Fortunes frame,
Those, who will nothing Stake, no Prize can Claim.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lorenzo, and Don Philip, Meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: MY Lord, you're well met—I am glad I have the good Fortune to light on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Have you wanted me on any urgent Oc∣casion? Pray what may be the Business?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: I have an humble Petition to your Lordship, and you must promise me to Grant it, before I tell the Consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: That's very fine indeed, that I must give my Consent, and not know to what—I suppose this is something in Relation to my Daughter.—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: No my Lord, what I come now to Re∣quest is in behalf of a Friend.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Be it as it will, Don Philip may Command me in any Thing, as far as the Rules of Honour will permit.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: I hope my Lord, I shall never be so Ungenerous as to require any thing that wou'd be a Stain to your Honour—But my Petition to you is in behalf of Sir Charles Winlove, an English Gentleman, who I am inform'd your Lord∣ship sent this Day a Prisoner to the Castle.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: D'ye know him?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P:
Very well, my Lord, and know him to be a Man of Honour—I ow'd my Life to him
when I was in England—And ever after, there was such a Friendship between us, that during my Continuance there, we were seldom or never asunder.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I am glad to hear so Honourable a Cha∣racter of the Gentleman—I am sorry for his Misfortunes, but he has Injur'd a particular Friend of mine in relation to his Daughter.—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: My Lord, that proceeds from the Wildness of his Youth—We are all Subject to such Faults—Sir Charles is what we Esteem a fine Gentleman, and the English are all Men of Gallantry and Intrigue—Besides, if a young Lady is inclinable to be kind, what brisk Ca∣valier can refuse her Favours?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I wish I cou'd serve him with Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: You may; consider, to Confine a young Gentleman from his Pleasures, is blasting him in the Bloom of his Life—Besides, Liberty is the very Soul of the English, and they had ra∣ther submit to Honourable Death, than Bondage.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: What can I do in this Affair?—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: If your Lordship will allow him to be a Prisoner at Large, till you hear farther from Madrid, my Honour shall be the Pledge for his Security.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I shou'd be willing to Consent to this, were I to follow my own Inclinations—But his Commitment to the Castle is for Murder.—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: My Lord, I know the Circumstances of the Story, and the People concern'd in't, ex∣cept the young Lady—Therefore if you'll be∣lieve, me when I left Madrid, the wounded Cavalier was not actually Dead—Nay, there was some hopes of his Recovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P:
I had no such Intimation in the Letter I receiv'd this Morning—But now I think on't,
my Friend may write so, because I shou'd secure his Daughter—Are you sure of this?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Upon my Honour my Lord, I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Then for once I'll yield to your Desires—Follow me, and I'll give you my Signet—The Keeper knowing you, will obey you at the sight of it—But remember I put my Honour into your Hands, therefore use it with Discretion.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: My Lord, you may depend on it—Even Friendship it self shou'd not win me to be∣tray my Trust.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Certainly never Man was so Unfortu∣nate—Sure the Fates have join'd in Conspira∣cy to plague me in my Amours—Nay, ev'n the Winds to compleat my Ruin, have oppos'd my Passage to England—A very fine Comfort 'tis indeed—Here am I in Confinement, without a Friend to come to my Assistance—What the Devil shall I do in this Exigence of Fortune?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Aye, think Sir—We are in a fine place indeed—See what it is to be a great Man! The Governour provides you with Lodgings here in the Metropolitan Castle—Where for the Se∣curity of your Person, he orders you a Retinue of Guards, as if in the King's Palace—But me∣thinks these Honours Sir have a very Scurvy Countenance—Pray Heav'n we an't Exalted to the highest Posts of the Nation.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P:
I don't know what to think—The Governour is certainly a Man of Quality, and can have no other View in this than the Service of his Country—All that makes me dubious is, whe∣ther
I am a Prisoner for my own Sake or the Lady's.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: For both Sir, but here comes one that will solve the Riddle—A Woman in a VEIL—There's certainly Witchcraft in these Women, for no sooner Name a She-Devil, but you find her at your Elbow.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Cavalier! I come from a Fair Lady that was taken a Prisoner with you this Morning—Read that

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: How does she bear her Confinement?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Like a Turtle moaning for its Mate—The poor Lady has fretted till she's in the Spleen.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: I am sorry that I shou'd be the Cause of her Misfortunes—But Vexations in Love are like Cloudy April Showers, they bring forth the Flowers of delight, to be chear'd by the Warmth of the Sun in its full Lustre—But now for the Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: They say a Witch commonly appears a∣gainst ill Weather—Like a Porpus before a Storm—Now prithee Damsel what can we Prognosticate from the Sight of you?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Prithee Fellow learn more Manners, and to be less pert in your Discourse.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Nay, if you talk of being pert, Commend me to a Chambermaid faith—But prithee Child don't affect the Airs of your Mistress thus—I an't so damnably in Love with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Hold your Tongue Sirrah—My Little Emissary, tell the Lady I'll wait on her at Night according to her Command—till when, farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Don't fail.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: You'll wait on her at Night! Ha, ha, ha, Sir, 'tis already dark—Therefore if you have the Keys of the Castle in your Pocket, let us shut the Doors after us, and take up with another new Lodging.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Sirrah, I have a Key, and a Gold one too—Look here Rascal—This by the Virtue of a Glittering Smile can make the Prison Doors fly Open, and turn Confinement into Liberty.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Why truly, it has an alluring Look—But methinks a little Aqua fortis now wou'd be of much more Service.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Why you Blockhead, d'ye think I in∣tend to apply it to the Bars, to break Jayl?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Aye Sir, if you intend to keep your Ap∣pointment with the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Yes, I do intend to keep it, and there∣fore this Goes to the Keeper.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: So it may—But I believe he has more Wit than to give you your Freedom, if it does.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: You are mistaken Sirrah—What! Can it bribe a Favourite to Betray his Prince, a Senate their Country, or a Courtier his nearest Friend—Yet fail to tempt such Fellows as Jayl-Keepers to be perfidious to their Trust?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: One Question more Sir—Have you quite forgot Fidelia.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: The Absence of an old Mistress makes room for a new one—Therefore I have blotted her from my Fancy, like a Painter that strikes one form out of his Cloth, to lay in another.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Sir, Consider, and don't run headlong thus to your own Destruction.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Aspin turning Philospher.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Aye Don Philip, my Servant apes a Philosopher, like a Cobler that leaves his Stall for a Tub—And sets up for one of our Reformed Teachers.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Perhaps he fancies himself Inspir'd, and thinks to deliver you by his Inspiration to ano∣ther Place—I'm sure I'm sorry to see you where you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Don Philip, You are happy in the Af∣fections of a fair Lady—Therefore let not your Concern for me be an Interruption in your Plea∣sure.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: My Mistress and my Friend share my Heart—And I can never rejoyce in one when I am concern'd for the other—Is there any thing I can serve you in?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: There is—You know I told you this Morning I had struck up a new Amour—I can't tell you the Ladies Name, for she's a Stranger to me—But had I my Liberty, I might have the Happiness of seeing her to Night.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Very well, Sir Charles—I find 'tis not in the Power of Fortune to reclaim you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: No faith, I am resolv'd to overcome her ill Nature by Laughing at it—And let what will happen, it shall never alter my Hu∣mour, nor be an Interruption to my Pleasures.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Very finely resolv'd indeed—But suppose Sir Charles I shou'd gain you your freedom now, what Security shall I have of your Return?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: By the Honour of an English Man I'll return Agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: I hope he'll have more Wit than to keep his Word tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Enough—Here, who waits there.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: D'ye know this Signet?

SP.SPEAKER: Keep.
SP.P: Yes, 'tis my Lord Governour's.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: I command you by Vertue of this to shew that Gentleman the same Respect as to my self—Give him his Liberty—I'll answer it to the Governour.

SP.SPEAKER: Keep.
SP.P: I obey your Orders.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Here, take this for your Civility.

SP.SPEAKER: Keep.
SP.P: Sir I thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Now you have your Liberty! You must take me along with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: No, I won't draw you into Dangers—that wou'd be an ill return for so great an Obli∣gation.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: That excuse won't serve—I am re∣solv'd to see this Mistress of Yours Sir Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Don't take it ill if I refuse you—For ev'n Pylades and Orestes had their separate Secrets—This Lady is a Woman of Quality, and shou'd I serve her so, she'll resent it.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: How can you be satisfy'd she's a Wo∣man of Quality, if you never saw her Face.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Her Manners and Appearance are a convincing Proof of that.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: I thought Sir Charles you had known the ways of your own Country better—perhaps she may be a Courtezan.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Cha.
SP.P: No, No, I am convinc'd of the Con∣trary—These Ladies are easily distinguish'd by their Airs from Women of Quality—You may depend on it I am not so easily impos'd upon.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: I won't press farther then against your Inclinations—Good Night, I'll see you again to¦Morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: So! Now Fortune begins to turn her Wheel—Some lucky Spoke may rise Quickly to my Advantage—Aspin, lend me your Pi∣stol for my Security.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Must I stay behind Sir—'tis a Servant's Duty to follow his Master's Heels—Besides, I dont like this place for an Amusement.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Come along then—It grows Late, therefore I'll take a short turn, and wait for the happy Signal.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: The Invention of a Wit, the Courage of a Knight-Errant, and the Conduct of a Politician, are all Comprehended in an Adventerous Lover—First we lay the Scene of an Assignation, then enter into the Part, and if got into the Action, have a thousand Incidents to bring us off agen—I'm now assur'd, let what will interpose, Love and Resolution can never fail of Success.
Is the Coast clear?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Yes Madam—The Governour's gone to his Repose.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Where's Fidelia?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: In the same Condition.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: And Don Philip.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: He's just come in, and retir'd to his A∣partment.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Are all the Family at Rest?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: There's not one stirring in the House Ma∣dam

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Then seek out for the Cavalier. So! Now I have nothing left me to fear, but a Disappointment from Sir Charles—Yet why that? We young Girls can break the Prison of a Father's House to fly to our Admirers, therefore such a Gallant as he can never want a Stratagem to release himself—Beside, if Love's his Guide, Fortune must be his Assistant—But here they Come.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Tread softly, Leonora's in the next Room undressing, and the Governour lies near.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Thanks to my Stars, that thro' the folds of Darkness I'm come at length to the Re∣gions of Light.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: I'll retire, that I may give you notice if any thing should happen.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Egad, this Girl's worth Gold—She knows Civilly how to withdraw, and leave a pair of Lovers together.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: You're a fine Courtier truly, to let a Lady when she comes to see you, be carry'd away in Captivity—I thought by this time to have heard that you had broke your Prison, Slain your Guards, and Conquer'd whole Armies to have Gain'd my Freedom—Then you had been a Lo∣ver indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Madam, I thought it wou'd be a much greater Pleasure in a happy Meeting to compleat my Blessing, than to turn Mad-man, and be run thro' for aiming at Impossibilities.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P:
This is a Satisfaction that every Lover can give, because 'tis a Pleasure to him—But your Death wou'd have Chronicled my Fame in Ro∣mance, to have been read by young Virgins in
After-ages, that such a one Lov'd me so, he dy'd for the sake of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Lookee Madam, I am not so Roman∣tick as to Die for the sake of being read in a Novel, to divert Girls in the Green-Sickness—My intention is to Live for the End I was Crea∣ted, to propagate my Generation—Therefore as I am a Prisoner upon Parole, and must return by break of Day to the Castle; let us reap the Advantages of Love, Night, and Opportunity.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: A fine Speech indeed, you are like the Atheist, all for Pleasures at the present, and ne∣ver have a Thought of Futurity—I expected you wou'd have prov'd a Paris, at least—That is, have proffer'd to have carry'd me to a safe Ar∣bour, and there to have given your self up for Life, as a personal Security for your Love.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: For Life too much resembles Marri∣age, which is the disagreeable part of Love—Besides, my Honour's engag'd for my Return.—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Love is the nicest Point of Honour—Therefore the Engagement is of greater Force—But I know the Reason why you are thus Re∣serv'd—You have a Pre-engagement on your Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: 'Tis true, I have Lov'd another; but one Love, like one Power, yields to a Superior.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Very well Sir Charles, I see you are too Inconstant to be Trusted—For now by your own Confession, shou'd you see another, I must yield your Heart to her Beauty, because you may chance to think it Superior to mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Madam, That's impossible—For the Charms of your Wit so Conspire with those of your Beauty, that they must fix ev'n Inconstan∣cy itself.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I esteem such Flights but as Complements Sir Charles—And a Complement to a Lady, like a Poetical flattering Panegyrick, is the se∣verest Satire—For it shows the Persons what they ought to be in the Reverse of what they are.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: What Arguments can I then use to Convince you of my Affections?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: None, I shou'd as soon take an Atheist for a Man of Sense; a Wit for a Politician; or a Po∣litician for a Man of Honour; as a Libertine like Sir Charles, for a Lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: But Madam, can you have so mean an Opinion of your own Desert, as to believe a Heart that has been your Captive, can ever break your Chains?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: No! but you have been False already, and Inconstancy is as bad a Proof of Love, as Scurrility is of Wit—The one proceeds from a false Genius, and the other from a degenerate Passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Come, this is trifling away the happy Minutes. [A Pistol fir'd.] Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: What means that Noise?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: This is certainly my Dog of a Ser∣vant.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Hast, or you'll be discover'd, the Go∣vernour's Rising.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Where shall I hide my self?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Alass, here's no Conveniency—There∣fore fly quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: If he goes out at the Door, the Governor meets him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: What shall I do then?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Jacomo, Pedro, Lights there.—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: They're coming here.—

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Then there's no Time to trifle—Out, out of the Window Sir, quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Out of the Window! so shall I break my Neck, to preserve a Lady's Reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Lights, Lights there quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: For Heaven's sake Sir Charles, fly for my Honour; and your Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Fly! 'Sdeath Madam, What do you mean? D'ye think I have Wings like a Cupid to fly out of the Window.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Your stay will Ruin me Sir Charles—Besides, you may safely get by a Balcony from my Closet into the Court-Yard.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: This comes now, of making ill use of one's Time. Well, I must run the Risque, but a Pox on me, if ever I draw my self into these Scrapes agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: What Course shall we take now?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Hast to my Daughter's Chamber there.
Some of you follow me to Search the Court-Yard.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Hark, there are some of them coming here.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Nay, then Out go the Lights—Now per∣haps they'll conclude we are at Rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I shiver with Apprehensions—My Fa∣ther will certainly find Sir Charles, or his Man in the Court-Yard.—

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: That we must leave to Fortune Madam,—In the mean time, let us retire softly, for fear we are Discover'd.
SP.STAGE: Enter Sir Charles Feeling his Way.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Vexations are always the Fruits of an Intrigue—What shall I do? Where's my Rascal∣ly Servant? The House is alarm'd, and I am in the Dark within the Verge of the Governour's Palace.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: I have rais'd the House with the Report of my Pistol, and now Security's the Word—Odd 'tis very dark—Every Step I have taken, I have knock'd my Head against some Post or Wall, till I have almost beat out my Brains.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: If I am not mistaken, I hear the tread of a Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: I warrant you now my Master is so full of his Sport with the Lady, that he hears nothing of this Disturbance—Odd, I can but Laugh to think how he'll look when he is Catch'd in the nick of his Performance.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: There's certainly somebody in this Yard—If I don't take care, I may chance to lose my Life before I know where I am—There∣fore old Friend stand to my Assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: Aspin.
SP.P: Hark, I hear somebody—They steal softly, thinking to Catch me here before I am aware of 'em—These Spaniards are damn'd Fel∣lows—They love to run a Man thro' in the dark—Odd, I'll up with my Heels, and trust fear to be my Guide—O Lud, I am Caught! Help! Help!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Whoever you are, if you offer to stir an Inch, you're a dead Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Aspin.
SP.P: Oh Lud Sir, save my Life, and I'll Peach—I'll tell you the whole Plot.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Oh! Is it your Worship Sir?—This is all owing to you, you Rascal.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Have you Search'd every Place carefully? Follow me, some of you to the Court-Yard.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Egad the Enemy will be at our Heels presently—Sirrah, March after me by the Sound of my tread—Ha! What have I stumbled against? A Chair! It seems set in my Way by Fortune—Lights are Coming—I'll in here, and hide my self.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Sir, let me come in too, for if I am taken I shall either be Hang'd like a Dog, or knock'd o'the Head like an Ox.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Sirrah, here's no Room—Therefore shift for your self.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: They're all Coming; for Heaven's sake, let me sit upon your Knee Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Get out you Rascal, I shall be Dis∣cover'd by your Folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: This is very Barbarous—I wish I cou'd find out a Horsepond—I'd run up to my Neck to secure my self—Here they Come—If I am Caught. I'll be Reveng'd and Peach, I'm re∣solv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Have you been at Leonora's Chamber?

SP.SPEAKER: Ist. Servant.
SP.P: Yes my Lord—And I believe she's in her Bed, for I saw no Light.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I thought I heard somebody leap out of her Window—Secure the Gates.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Don Philip! Have you caught the alarm too?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: My Lord, I heard a Noise in my Room, and came to see what's the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: We thought somebody had broke in—but we can find no one but our own Family.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Have you made a diligent Search, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: We have search'd almost every where—except any one's hid in that Chair.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Give me the Light, I'll see the Chair, Sir Cha. nods at him to take no Notice.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Is there any one?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: No my Lord—Death and Confusion! Sir Charles there!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: 'Twas a Mistake betwixt Sleep and Waking—I'll retire to rest agen—A good Repose to you Don Philip.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: The like to your Lordship.

So, they are all retir'd now, to their respective Chambers—My Lord wou'd have perswaded me this was an Illusion—So he thinks to deceive me, whilst I deceive him—We wou'd both hide the Disgrace from each other.—Hist, Sir Charles you may come forth now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Dear Philip thou art the best of Friends.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Am I not to be made a Property to my own Shame? Is this Generous Usage?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: What mean you?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: You have Supplanted me in Leonora.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: 'Tis a Mistake—I came to a young Lady that's a Prisoner—Who was taken with me.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: That's a poor Evasion, and below a Man of Honour—I know the Reason now why you refus'd to admit of my Company—Besides, there's no such Person in the House—Lookee Sir Charles I shall expect Satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Lookee, you are Mad—For Jealousy is no other than Madness—I tell you there is such a Lady; Perhaps you may be so blinded with Love, that you may not regard any Body in the Family but the Governour and his Daugh∣ter—But if what I say is not true, to Morrow you shall have what Satisfaction you require.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Till then Farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Farewell ill you come to your Senses agen—So! I have brought my self to a fine Pass indeed—I have kill'd one hot-brain'd Fool for his Jealousy, and now to Compleat my Mis∣fortune, he too has Catch'd the Infection—What shall I do? If I stay here and trust the Inquisition, 'tis ten times more unmerciful than a Middlesex Jury—A Man can never have fair Play for his Life—To touch cold Iron and come off like a Gentleman—Shall I than lay old on this Op∣portunity, and make my Escape? No! They shall never say an English Man's so base a Coward.

Q.L: Let the hot Spaniard boast his Vertue here,
And Honour's Loss in Jealous Notions fear.
A Briton scorns to prove his Country's Shame,
And rather Hazard's Life, than taints his Fame.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: COME, come Madam, I'm not to be so Impos'd upon! you may deny it as long as you please, but you can't perswade me out of my Senses—Did not I last Night actu∣ally see Sir Charles hid under your Window in the Court-Yard.—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Suppose you did Sir.—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Then Madam, I can suppose it to be no Advantage to your Character—S'death, am I to be made a Property! a meer Pander; to car∣ry on an Intrigue against my own Honour?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Very well! go on Sir, go on.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: So, I can Madam, is it Prudent for a young Lady just upon her Marriage, to entertain a Cavalier alone at Midnight—Nay, in her own Chamber too! unknown to her Father, or any one that shou'd be the Guardian of her Ho∣nour—Such Conduct is mighty Reputable in∣deed Madam.—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P:
Suppose such a Person was here Sir—Is there no other Place that cou'd Entertain him
but my Appartment? Am I the only Person he cou'd come to—Must I be accountable for his being here?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: No Madam, by no means—'Tis pro∣bable to believe a Person of his Quality, might have an Affair with one of your Servants only—S'death, d'ye take me for a Fool! is there any other young Lady in the House? Lookee Madam, I shou'd not so tamely take this of Sir Charles, but that I scorn to Insult a Man in his Misfor∣tunes—However, I can be yet capable of Re∣sentment—For know, I'll immediately Demand my Contract of your Father, and return back to Madrid.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: If I let him go, this may give room for Suspicion, and Suspicion will bring a Discovery. Hold Sir—Not that 'tis worth my while to clear my Innocence, for your Sake, but for my Fathers: Know then, here is another young La∣dy in this House.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Aye! who? tell me that pray Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: The Prisoner Sir—I shall have a fine time to satisfie your Scruples.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: The Prisoner! ha, ha, ha! you are both in the same Story I find—Your Scheme is excellently well laid—Were I a zealous Do∣tard, or a British Husband, perhaps I might be Credulous enough to believe any thing—But this Deceit won't take, it won't Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: How! what Indecency have I been guilty of to Merit this Usage? But know, since you are still resolv'd to traduce my Honour, there are those Sir, that will Vindicate it—This is not to be born with Patience.—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P:
Nay Madam, don't disorder your self thus—For you may henceforth meet Sir Charles
as often as you please—And expose your Repu∣tation as much as you think fit, it shall never give me any further Uneasiness I can assure you Madam.—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Insolent? before you had resolv'd to treat me after this Manner, you might at least have ask'd my Father if there was no such Person in the House—Is this the Return for all his Friend∣ship? But here comes the Lady her self, I shall leave her to give you Satisfaction. Provoking Man!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Ha! what do I see? Here comes a young Lady indeed! I'm afraid Jealousy has carry'd me too far—Soft! I'll lay aside this Heat a little, if possible.—
But still methinks my Choler rises so, I know not how to suppress it.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Here we may learn their Discourse. Me∣thinks, tho' I am partly in Fault, I am exaspe∣rated at such Treatment.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Ha! who's here? What can be the mean∣ing of this?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Nay Madam, don't start—I hope the Sight of me has not put you in a Consterna∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Sir, I came to meet a Friend, and being lost in Thought, Pardon me if I was a little Sur∣priz'd.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Madam, whoever you came to Meet, and however strange it may seem to you, you are the only Person I cou'd wish for at present.—

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Me Sir! I don't know that ever I saw you in my Life before.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Very like so Madam—But howe∣ver you may be Surpriz'd, you have been the Cause that has rais'd this Disorder in my Soul, and 'tis in your Power alone to appease it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: I the Cause of your Disorder Sir! cer∣tainly the Man's Mad.—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Pardon me, if my Temper's a little Ruffled.—Perhaps I may be Impertinent—But if you have the least Compassion, I beg you An∣swer me to one Particular.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: With all my Heart Sir, if it lies in my Power—What can the Man mean? He looks as if he was Distracted.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Answer me directly and sincerely Madam—For my Scruples are as of great a Consequence, as those of troubled Minds, that apply to Casuists for Ease.—

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Sir, you Surprize me wonderfully—What Satisfaction can I that am a Stranger, give you?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: The Greatest! and only in one trivi∣al Answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: What is it Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: D'ye know such a Person, as Sir Charles Winlove, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: How Sir? your Question startles me in∣deed.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: It need not, for as I am a Cavalier, I ask you for no treacherous Design—Therefore be kind, and ease me with an Answer.—

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: How earnest and concern'd he seems! Sure he has no Design to offer Love—Perhaps he may come as a Spy to betray me—I know not what to think.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Madam, I conjure von by all the Soft∣ness of your Sex, to free me from my Doubts—For the whole quiet of my Soul depends on what you say.—

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: I will—Whate're the Consequence may prove, I leave to you—Know then, I scorn on any Terms to deny my Affection for Sir Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: This Satisfaction cheers me indeed—Curse on my jealous Folly—Are you a Na∣tive of Valencia Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: No Sir, I am totally a Stranger to it—Love, that has been my Guide to Ruin, was my Director hither—But now Sir, Answer me a Question in my Turn—Are you Acquainted with Sir Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Nay, if they come to Particulars, we are lost agen.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Madam, I know him well—He is my dearest Friend! How have I wrong'd him with Suspicions.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Your Friend say you? Can you give me any Tydings of him Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: I Question not but he is return'd in safety to the Castle—I am now immediately going to him about some Affairs of Consequence, in the mean time depend on my Interest to serve you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: In the Castle! Said he so, or did I dream? Oh! For the Wings of Love to haste and be Con∣vinc'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: So, here's another Hare started—Where are you going in such hast, Fidelia.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Madam, I hear that the Cavalier that I'm in Search of is a Prisoner in the Castle, therefore I must immediately fetch my VEIL, and hasten to see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Now am I more Unfortunate than ever! what Stop shall I put to this?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Madam, You must again Consult your Wit; you see Discoveries gather like Clouds, and I'm afraid the main Storm will come ratling upon us immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I was never so provok'd in my Life, as I was at Don Philip's Jealousies, and all this I under∣go for a Person that I'm not secure of—For as Fidelia was the first Object of Sir Charles's Affe∣ctions, she'll still be the Mistress of his Heart—And Possession there, as in the Law, will make her Eleven Points before me.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Then Madam, in my humble Opinion 'twill be better to drop this Amour—This Lady will in the End Discover all—Therefore I think it better to forsake a Victory than to lose it.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I am of the same Opinion—But what shall I do in this Affair?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: E'en follow the Example of declining Cour∣tiers—That is, whilst you've Possession of his Affections, think 'tis more Honour to Resign than to be Remov'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: But I mean now I have gone so far, how shall I retire without hazarding my Reputation?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Shou'd you trust his Love, even the Suc∣cess of your Amour will be of ill Consequence—Therefore Appoint another Assignation with him—Let her into the Secret, so far as not to give her uneasiness, and carry her with you to meet him.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Prudently Advis'd—But see, she comes I must not let her go, for that will ruin all.
Are you resolv'd upon this Adventure Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Yes, now I know where Sir Charles is, me thinks I am all Impatience to see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I'd advise you to apply your self to Second Thoughts, and 'ere you fix upon a Resolution, to weigh well the Consequence of this Proceeding.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: The Consequence!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Ave, consider, you are no more Mistress of your Liberty—But are here now in Con∣finement.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: In Confinement Madam! I desire you to Explain your Meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Then in short to clear up the Mystery at once; my Father is an intimate Friend of yours—And for the sake of that Friendship, he has here engag'd to Secure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Am I so barbarously Betray'd then? I thought Madam, I had come to the Governor's Daughter for Refuge, and not to a Prison to be Confin'd in.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I can't but make an Allowance to your Surprize—And therefore yield to your Resent∣ment. But I cou'd wish you wou'd make your self a little Easy—For perhaps, I might yet propose a Method for your Satisfaction.
Ha! my Father! for Heaven's sake Calm your self a little.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: What makes the Lady appear in such a Disorder Leonora?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Now the Cloud is gather'd, it begins to break before we are Prepar'd for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: A Trifle only, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: No Madam, 'tis no Trifle—My Lord, I think I have Reason to be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: How Madam—I hope you have receiv'd no ill Treatment from any of my Family.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: The Lady was going Abroad without your Leave, and I believe She may take it Ill, because I told her the Consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: How Madam, I am sorry you shou'd be led into such an Error?

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: My Lord, I confess a Point of Ceremony might have oblig'd me to ask'd your Leave—But either there is a Mistake on your Side, or if you rightly knew me, and the cause why I am here, I believe you wou'd not refuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: 'Tis because I know both Madam, I do refuse you—And tho' you may Command what Free∣dom you please in the House, I beg you still to Remember you're a Prisoner.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: A Prisoner! Upon what Account! By what Authority my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Madam, My Authority was never won't to be call'd in Question—Besides, I thought I had satisfy'd you as to that when I siez'd you Ye∣sterday with Sir Charles Winlove.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Seiz'd me Yesterday with Sir Charles Win∣love! What does your Lordship mean? In short, I believe you're impos'd upon.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Madam, If my Senses are right, I am cer∣tain I am not impos'd upon—And you must Pardon me if I can't consent to be so—Did not I bring you Yesterday here in Custody?

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: No my Lord, this Lady and her Servant can Witness I came here alone, and on my own Accord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P:
To Contradict the Fair may seem a breach of Respect due to the Sex—Therefore I can make
you no other Answer than this, that when young Ladies are in Love, 'tis no wonder if they are thus forgetful.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Madam, I desire that you'll Speak, and satisfy my Lord as to your Knowledge in this Affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Madam, You see my Lord is already sa∣tisfy'd—Besides, since you are wound in the Toil, I shan't draw my self into the Snare to de∣liver you

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: My Lord, this is very hard, thus to be shut out of the Light of Reason, to remain in the darkness of Mystery.

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.P: Come along there—Bring him before my Lord Governour

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Ha! What new Disturbance is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Gentlemen, dear Gentlemen, don't Col∣lar me so furiously—Consider, to Choak a Man without a halter is against Law—Besides, I am no Turk, and therefore am not Ambitious of the Honour of being Strangled like a Grand Vizier

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Ha! 'Tis Sir Charles's Man—Perhaps this may be of an ill Consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Let go your hold of him: What's the mean∣ing of all this?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Servant.
SP.P: My Lord, this is the Fellow that made the Disturbance last Night—For Search∣ing him we found this Pistol conceal'd in one of his Pockets.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Servant.
