SP.P: My Lord, we believe he came upon a very Traiterous Design—For we discover'd him hid under one of the Maid's Beds.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: A very pretty Fellow indeed—Take him away, I'll consider of a Punishment for the Rascal.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: This is an admirable Place for Law and Discipline—Priests enjoyn Pennance for Len∣en Mortification, and Judges hang Folks without hearing their Defence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: D'ye you presume to Murmer in my Pre∣sence, Sirrah? What have you to say for your self?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Say! Why nothing my Lord! I am unpro∣vided with Counsel, and therefore my Motion is that I may defer my Tryal.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Prithee Fellow answer me to the Purpose—What are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Not Guilty my Lord, not Guilty.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I mean Sirrah, who are you? What's your Business here?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: My Lord, as to who I am, I am my Ma∣ster's Servant; and as to my Business here, if you don't like my Company, I am ready to take my Leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Stop him! I never saw so impudent a Fel∣low before.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: They say Madam, he's an English Man's Servant, but I'm sure he has an Irish Assurance.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Pray Heav'n he has Assurance enough to bring himself off, for I'm afraid this will open the Scene, and immediately discover all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Harkee Fellow—Give some Account of your self, what Profession are you of?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Why my Lord, I wait upon my Master—In his Chamber I'm his Valet in Ordinary, some∣times his Pimp in Extraordinary, and commonly have the Honour to be of his Cabinet Counsel.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Thou art an Excellent Rascal indeed—Prithee Fellow, who is your Master?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: So! These Great Folks are as forgetful of every thing, as they are of their Promises—Is then my Face a Strauger to your Lordship?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Sirrah, if you had Gold enough in your Pocket to answer the Brass of your Countenance, you might outvy the most impudent Courtier in Europe—But don't presume to Trifle with me thus any longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Then to refresh your Memory my Lord, I am Sir Charles Winlove's Servant, and your Lord∣ship's Prisoner at Discretion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Ha! I had forgot the Rogue indeed!—So Madam, does the Scene now begin to open or not.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: My Lord, I am innocent of the Charge, and therefore am satisfy'd this can have no Re∣lation to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: 'Tis well Madam, this will appear im∣mediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I'm afraid Flora, now comes the Clue that will unravel the Mystery at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: In the first Place Rascal, what provok'd you to make such a Disturbance?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Why my Lord, I was assaulted in your Lordship's Court-Yard by a great Mastiff, and I u∣sed that Pistol as an Instrument to allay his Fury.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: In the mean time, Where was your Master?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Only playing a Game or two with my Lady, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Very well Madam, Go on Sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Nay my Lord, I know no more than that he was carried away from me by a She-Confident of the Lady's, Vulgarly call'd a Cham∣bermaid?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Here's a Treacherous Rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: How Flora—Did you Conduct him to the Lady's Chamber?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: I my Lord! Certainly the Fellow has not the Impudence to say so.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Nay, I had not such Cat's Eyes to know any one in the Dark, but methinks your Voice agrees much with that pert Lady's, that brought the Letter to my Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: So, this Raskal will betray all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Then this was a concerted Business I find,—Sirrah, let me hear no more of these Pra∣ctices—Discharge the Fellow, and let him re∣turn to his Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: So! They say Confess and be Hang'd—But I am come as clear off by turning Evi∣dence, as if I had bought off the Verdict of a Jury.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: So Madam, I hope now you'll no lon∣ger deny your Correspondence with Sir Charles Winlove—But I am sorry (for the sake of my Respect to your Father) to see you still so regardless of your Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: My Lord, believe me I am Innocent—And if Sir Charles has had any Affair here—'Tis with some of your own Fa∣mily.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I cou'd almost wish to be Ignorant of such convincing Proofs in relation to this Af∣fair—But you must Pardon me, if I grow now to be more Cautious of your Proceedings—Flora, shou'd I find you in the least Concern'd in this, you shall no longer remain in my House.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Now is my Time—Methinks your Countenance Madam, speaks a surprize at these Proceedings.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: I own I am so Confus'd, that I scarce know whether this is Reality, or an Illusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I see Fidelia you are a little Acquaint∣ed with the Artifices of Love, tho' you are Caught in the Snare—Can't you dive into the Mystery of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: An ignorant Innocence is peculiar to our Sex, and to dive into Mystery, they say is a Sin in any one but a Brother of the Pro∣fession—Therefore I shall let it rest, till it unravels it self.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Were I in your Case, I should rather be fired with a Woman's Curiosity, than be so unmov'd at the Turns of my Fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: I am already satisfy'd of my Misfor∣tunes, therefore Cùriosity might betray me to a knowledge that perhaps wou'd heighten 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Alass Fidelia, I am in as great a Con∣cern as you are—For my Quiet is E∣qually at Stake with yours—But if you will consent to come into my Measures, there is yet a Way to make us both Easy.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Propose it, for methinks I cou'd Em∣brace any Method that cou'd bring me to the Sight of Sir Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Know then, my Father has Contracted me to one, who has all the Qualities that can make him agreeable—Notwithstanding which I have lately Entertain'd the Addres∣ses of an English Cavalier, who now proves to be the very same you were speaking of.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: What! Sir Charles Winlove Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: The same.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: How! After having ruin'd me, Can he be so Perfidious to make his Addresses to ano∣ther! False Man!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Alass, all Men are the same Fidelia—In short they use us as Children do their Toys, are Fond of us at first—But quickly neglect us to follow New Fancies—But to proceed—Yesterday I met this Sir Charles at his Lodgings, where my Father came attended with Officers, and Siez'd us to∣gether—He was Carry'd to the Castle, and I was brought Home conceal'd in a VEIL, where by the Circumstances of the Story, I find he mistook me for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Wou'd you be willing Madam, to resign your Interest in Sir Charles, provided I would stand to the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Yes Fidelia, you shall now see me throw off the Softness of a Lover, for the Craft of a Politician to serve you—And as a first Proof of my Friendship, I'll Write to him as from my self; Flora shall carry the Let∣ter, and if he can get his Liberty, I'll En∣gage he shall meet us in two Hours at ano∣ther Place.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: This is as I cou'd wish Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: One thing more—I overheard your Discourse with that Cavalier who is to be my Husband—I see his Jealousies are Cur'd, and all Points are now clear'd to my Content.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Let us then be Quick in our Proceed∣ings.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: With all my Heart, We'll now retire and I'll Write immediately to Sir Charles—Flora, be ready within Call to attend us.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P:
So, my Lady is now come off agen to her Satisfaction—If our Sex were as prudent
in Resolution, as they are Quick at Inventi∣on, they would not prove such weak Fools to the Men—However, I have learnt now, if Occasion serves, to carry on an Intrigue of my own—For I find, tho' Dangers happen from Love, Wit never fails to turn the Tables up∣on Fortune.

Q.L: Thus, when from Fate our Disappointments fall,

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: MY old Friend, once more I Congra∣tulate your Arrival to Valencia—You are come in good time to Vindicate the Hon∣our of your Family.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Come in a good Time say you! No, I am come in a very ill Time, I can't so much as thank you for your Civility—Harkee! Prithee look in my Face now! Am not I very much alter'd? Have not I something very rueful in my Coun∣tenance?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: What makes you Fancy so?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Because methinks I am no better than a Raven, I can croak nothing but bad News.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Come, come, be Chearful; all will go well again.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Yes truly! All is like to go mighty well indeed—My Son-in-Law, that was to be, has been desperately Wounded, my Daughter's run a∣way, and my Family's Disgraced for ever, and you expect me to be Chearful do you!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Nay, but hear Reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Nay, but I won't hear Reason! What have I to do with Reason, when I come in search of Revenge?—You say you have 'em both in your Custody!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Suppose I have! You tell me the wounded Cavalier is Recovered, then what pretence can I have of detaining Sir Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: No matter! I'll conceal his Recovery, and have the Dog suffer for his Death.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Fye! I am asham'd to see your Passion so overcome your Reason—Suppose your Daughter loves him.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Loves him! 'Sdeath who doubts but she does Love him! What, because the silly Baggage has been so weak as to suffer him to Ruin her, you would have me play the old Dotard, and be as great a Fool as my Daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Still you Mistake me—Why will you endeavour thus to widen the Breach, when I wou'd bring Matters to a Reconciliation?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: To a Reconciliation! Ha, ha, ha, this is pleasant indeed!—The Son of a Whore has Stole away my Daughter, and for ought I know she may have her Belly up to her Mouth, and you talk of bringing Matters to a Reconciliation!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: But suppose she shou'd Love him, and he shou'd have an equal Passion for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Why then my Curse be an equal Portion for them both.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Perhaps he wou'd Consent to Marry her.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Marry her! No, no, no! The young Fellows of this Age are not such Fools as to De∣bauch Women, and afterwards to Marry 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Nay, but—

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P:
Nay, but I know what it is to be a young Fellow! I tell you their Vows always Dissolve
with Virginities, and when the Fort's Surrender'd, all former Promises are void o'course.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: There are indeed too many of the Fair Sex in that unhappy Condition, but why shou'd you judge so hardly of your Daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Why shou'd I not judge so? Did she not run away with him? Has she not a Sanguine Com∣plection, and he a brawny Back? Is she not a promising Girl, and he a sprightly young Fellow?—Then why may not my Daughter happen to be with Child?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Still you perplex your Self with fancied Injuries only—Was she ever loose in her Behavi∣our?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: No, I always believ'd her to be a very modest Girl: But now she has certainly tasted of the Tree of Knowledge—He has open'd her Senses, and enter'd her into her Rudiments.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Did you ever Love your Daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Yes, too well; tho' indeed she was a ve∣ry good Girl, and deserv'd it—Nay, now I think of her, the Tears of Affection still come into my Eyes!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Indulge that Tenderness, and Reason will come o'Course—D'ye think I am your Friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: How shou'd I know that? We were Friends once indeed—That is, when we were Young—Then we us'd to drink our Bottle toge∣ther, ruin'd as many Girls, and made as many Cuckolds as any Rakehells in Europe—But now the Scene is Chang'd, you are my Lord Governour: Time, Absence, and State Affairs may have drove me out of your Memory.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Come, you shall see I am still your Friend, have Patience, and I'll endeavour to bring all to a right Understanding.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Patience!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Nay, nay, suppress your Choler, 'till you see whether you have Reason for it—I'll now imme∣diately go and propose an honourable Treaty to Sir Charles, in the mean time I beg you to re∣tire, and not see your Daughter 'till I return to tell you my Success.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Your Return will bring me a fine Account of Success indeed—We Men are certainly most unhappy Wretches—When we are young, we get Children in the Heat of our Blood, who when we come to be Old, grow Disobedient, and break our Hearts in order to get into our Estates—Well, I'll say no more, but I'll send this rebel Daughter of mine to a Nunnery, and there she shall mortify for the Sins of the Flesh—But for that Rogue that has Debauch'd her, if ever I see him again, I'll have his Blood tho' I meet him in a Sanctuary.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE. The Castle.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir Charles Winlove, and Don Phillip.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Sir Charles, I am now Convinc'd of your Innocence—My Suspicions were the fond, Errors of my Love, and as such I hope you'll E∣steem 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: I do When I consider that jealous Eyes always see thro' a Microscope, that magnifies the meanest Trifles, to seem as of the greatest Conse∣quence—But had you not been my Friend, I shou'd not so tamely have submitted to such U∣sage.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P:
I own the Rashness of my Folly to be great—Let Fools have the Obstinacy to per∣sist in their Errors—A generous Soul esteems it
rather as a Point of Honour; when Convinc'd, to acknowledge 'em—Therefore now let us turn the Discourse—I'll assure you Sir Charles, I think the Captive is very Beautiful.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Beautiful as ever I saw.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: But still methinks my Lady excels her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Every Lover is apt to think his own Mistress the most deserving—Mine has Wit as well as Beauty, and where the Lusciousness of one may Cloy the Appetite, the other Whets it agen, and makes all her Charms as agreeable as ever.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Wit and Beauty are two irresistable Weapons indeed; but I find you are in a fair Way to succeed in your Hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: No Faith—Notwithstanding she has so many Perfections, my Success was but very indifferent, whether the Inconstant Star that Go∣verns the Sex rul'd, I know not; but my Recep∣tion prov'd as great a Disappointment, as the Ac∣cident afterwards did a Surprise.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Oh, that was a meer Feint only to make a Tryal of your Love, I find you are not rightly acquainted with the Variety of a Lady's Humour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: No, nor ever shall, if 'tis so much ad∣dicted to Whimsey.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: But a Lover shou'd make it his Busi∣ness first to find the Temper of his Mistress, and then to study every Method that may promote her Pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Then I am not so much a Lover as to submit my Reason to Frenzy—For to study the Temper of a Woman, is like searching out for the Philosopher's Stone—A Man may spend his Estate, run Mad, and grow never the Wiser.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Notwithstanding your harsh Censure of the Sex, I wish I knew the Humour of my La∣dy so far as to gain Remission for my Folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: So, this is ever the Consequence of Jealousy—First you Quarrel with your Mistress for no Reason, and then are never easy till you're Reconcil'd

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: I own it is a Weakness indeed! but a Spaniard is so Unfortunate in his Passions, that he can no more avoid the rashness of Jealousy, than he can expel the heat of his Climate—But what Service Sir Charles can I do you now in your A∣mour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Why then once more to trust you as a Friend, I have this Day receiv'd a Letter from the Lady—But sure there are such Beauties in the Style, not Ovid is more soft, nor Horace more Satyrical.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: What are the Contents of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: 'Tis a kind Invitation to another Ap∣pointment; but Interspers'd with Reflections from an excellent Talent of Wit in Relation to my Servant's Carelessness—Here, prithee read it—And give me your Opinion.
So! Where have you been Sirrah?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Sir, I have run thro' as dangerous Adven∣tures as a Knight-Errant—But as I was Pre∣destinated to Act the Part of a Champion, I was prepar'd with Armour accordingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Were you so? Prithee let's hear the wonderful Description of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P:
Why Sir, Courage was the Support of my Back; Caution the Defence of my Breast; Wit was
my noble Head-piece; and this Pistol the Weapon with which I encounter'd Death and Destruction.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: That Pistol Sirrah! What occasion had you last Night to make it give such an Alarm?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Why Sir, I was Assaulted by no less than a fiery Dragon—In short, a great Mastiff flew at my Throat, and had I not had the Courage to have Encounter'd his Fury, I had certainly been torn in Pieces.—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Nay, then Sir Charles you must never be Angry with him for his Valour—Aspin has now rival'd the Fame of St. George—And I think his Statue ought to be set up in Memory of this Atchievement, as a second Honour to your Country.—

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: What is past was but a Tryal for the Cour∣age of a Hero—But the next Misfortune I fell into, requir'd the deepest Policy of a Statesman.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Aye! prithee what was that?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: I was this Morning discover'd by some of the Servants, and carry'd Viet Armis a Prisoner before my Lord Governour.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Aye! How came you off there, Aspin?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Oh Sir, I brought my self off with a wet Finger—First, the Governour ask'd me several Questions—I generously told him the Affair you had last Night with the Lady—Confession me∣rited Mercy, and I was immediately Discharg'd like a Man of Honour.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Were you so, Sirrah? Know then Ras∣cal, you have Discover'd all my Designs, and I'll this Moment make an Example of you.—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Hold Sir Charles—Consider, his Folly is below your Resentment.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: I have scarce Patience to suffer the Dog in my Sight—Rascal, deceitful Villain!

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Is this the Return for all the Dangers I have suffer'd—Well, 'tis an ungrateful Age—But I am not the first Man of Merit that has been slighted after his faithful Service.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Come, be pacify'd Sir Charles—All may be easily brought off agen—Here, take your Letter, I have Read it, and approve of the Design—But have you prepar'd any Place for your Appointment with the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: No, as to that Part I believe I must rely upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Then I can help you at a dead Lift—My Appartment has a Door into another Street—Order her to be carry'd the back Way, and as she's a Stranger to the Place, she may be easily deceiv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: I like the Proposal well—Aspin, go you this Moment and conduct 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: So, tho' we Men of Merit are so barba∣rously us'd, we are always wanted in a Case of Necessity.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Sirrah, no prating; mind what I say and go out of my Sight.
Now which way shall I obtain my Liberty for this Adventure?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Oh, I'll gain you that Freedom—and that you may the better by Daylight pass un∣known, I'll send you my Cloak, and you shall muffle your self in that—Ha! The Governour! What means this?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Don Philip, I see your Friendship is not like that of the World, a meer Counterfeit Pro∣fession—for you endeavour to serve the Person you Value, tho' you see him loaded with Affli∣ction.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: My Lord, Friendship is only shew'd in Adversity, a Man in Prosperity has abundance of Professors—But had he need of one, not a Friend amongst 'em all.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Your Friendship is mutual—Sir Charles sav'd your Life, and you'd now Return it with the Preservation of his—So that you both are Exceptions from the general Rule of the World, for there's scarce a Person in it besides your selves, can say I have a Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Because the reverse of Friendship is the Product of a degenerate Age; where Honesty passes for Folly; Perfidiousness for good Policy; and all manner of Knavery, for necessary Wis∣dom to thrive in the World—So that a Man can no more be assur'd of Friends in Adversity, than a King or Country in Distress—When those that shou'd be so, enrich themselves in their Destruction.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: You are a young Stoick indeed Sir Charles—However, I come now to stand your Friend, for want of Pity in your Case, wou'd be down-right Cruelty—And therefore give me leave to make some Proposals that may be to your Satisfaction—Don Philip, I hope you'll excuse me a little.—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: My Lord, I take my leave. Harkee Sir Charles, What shall I do in this Af∣fair?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Go and detain the Lady till I come, and d'ye hear, leave Orders with the Keeper for my Freedom.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Never fear—I'll manage all to the best Advantage.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I have this Morning receiv'd Advice of the Cavalier's Recovery, that was thought to have been Kill'd—This I must yet keep as a Secret, till I have brought Matters to bear.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Now my Lord, if you please, I am ready to receive your Proposals.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Sir Charles, I am come to you concerning an Affair of Consequence—You must know, Alonzo, the Father of Fidelia, and I, when young, were never separated from each other—Now I understand by a Letter from Madrid, you have lately depriv'd him of his Daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: How! Depriv'd him of her, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Aye, but methinks I would willingly heal this Breach—Therefore I'd advise you to find some means, by which you might reconcile your self to him, and restore the Honour of the young Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: My Lord, I understand you not—'Tis true I love Fidelia as my Life; but for her Hon∣our, it is not in the least forfeited on my Ac∣count.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Her Father is of a quite contrary Opini∣on—Therefore, if you have either a Value for your Self, or an Affection for the young Lady, you will consent to those means, that will Contri∣bute to her Ease, as well as to your own Se∣curity.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: My Lord, I own the Wildness of my Youth But I have so true an Affection for Fidelia, that for my Security, I prize it not in Comparison with her Content.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I see Sir Charles, you begin to Guess at my meaning—Therefore I Question not but to find you the Man of Honour, I was apt at first Sight to believe you—Her Fame upon your Account is very much become the Discourse of the World—Therefore to reconcile all, wou'd you be willing to accept her for a Wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: My Lord, I needed not this Prepara∣tion to Embrace such welcome Proposals.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Consent to that, and I'll engage your Pardon shall be secur'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: My Life is of as little Value to me now, as when I ran the Risque of forfeiting it for her—But for the looser Wishes that my In∣constancy has been guilty of (Cou'd I be so hap∣py to see her) they wou'd immediately Vanish at her Sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Know then Sir Charles, the Lady is still in Valencia.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: How! In Valencia, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: She has remain'd in Confinement at my House, ever since I Yesterday Siez'd her at your Lodgings.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Nay, then there is a Mistake in this—The Lady that was taken with me I can assure you is not Fidelia.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Her Father's Servant cou'd not be mista∣ken, and he afterwards saw her at my House.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: I know her Face too well to be de∣ceiv'd—The Lady that was taken with me I was a Stranger to.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: This is a pretty Contrivance indeed—In the first place the young Lady owns her self to be Fidelia, but at the same time denies a Corres∣pondence with you—And now you own a Cor∣respondence with her, but deny she is the Per∣son—Who was it then that you had an Assig∣nation with last Night at my House?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Since you have made a Discovery in that Affair, 'twas with the Lady that was siez'd with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: And that Lady you positively say is not Fidelia.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: I do my Lord, and if I am in my Senses, I am sure I can affirm it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Now she actually says she is—But denies that she has either seen you, or had any Discourse with you in Valencia.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Nay, then there is a farther Mystery in this! I am certain the Lady I met last Night was not Fidelia—Now if the Person you mean, that denies all this, shou'd prove to be her, then your Lordship is mistaken, for she can't be the same that was seiz'd with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Nay, there has been no Art Magick to Transform her, nor to change one Person to ano∣ther.—Therefore depend on't, she's the same—Now the Messenger from her Father went away satisfy'd, she was the right, and she upon Exami∣nation own'd herself to be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: This makes it all seem more Intricate still.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Come with me and let your Sight Con∣vince you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: By this he'll discover the Lady is gone Abroad, in order to meet me—What can I do? I must submit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Come along then Sir Charles—Methinks I am impatient to have this Riddle explain'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: And I the like my Lord—For I am sure as the Story lies now, there is so great a My∣stery in it, 'tis beyond the Power of a Churchman to unfold it, till we see farther.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, Don Philip's Apartment, in the Governor's House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Aspin, Fidelia, and Leonora VEIL'D.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P:
So, this is the first time that ever I turn'd Gentleman Usher—Methinks I make a notable
Figure in my Preferment—Nay, I don't know, but I may rise to be a great Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: The Creature looks as if he was in Love with himself—Harkee Fellow, where have you brought us?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Not a jot from your own Inclination I sup∣pose—Lookee Madam, it is my Master's Busi∣ness to answer your Questions—Here my Ser∣vice is at an end—Methinks I begin to have a Jantee Air already—I'll see how I can Comple∣ment—Ladies, I am your most humble Servant, and so I take my Leave of such illustrious Beau∣ties.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: I never saw such a Coxcomb in my Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Now we may venture to UNVEIL—For I know not where we are, by reason I never look'd out of the Chair.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Perhaps Sir Charles may have provided us one of his Mistresses Apartments—For I know not what to think of him, now he's grown so In∣constant.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Sure I'm no Stranger to this Place, Fidelia.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: They seem to be handsome Lodgings, and methinks are very prettily furnish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Ha! I am Surpriz'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: At what Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: As I Live, we are Betray'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: How! Heav'n forbid.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: We are in my Father's House, and this is Don Philip's Apartment.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: If so, here's Treachery indeed! What shall we do?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Nay, now here's a more convincing Proof, this is the very Door that opens into one of my Rooms.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Then Madam our Resolution must be quick as our Thought; for they'll certainly be here pre∣sently.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Oh for a Stratagem now to outwit em—Stay I'll look thro' the Keyhole, and see if I can discern my Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Is there any Body to be seen?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Yes, there's Flora working with her Needle at the Window.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Call softly Madam, perhaps she may hear you.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Flora, Hist, Flora—Don't you hear? Flora within. Who calls?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: 'Tis I—Fetch the Key that belongs to the Door, and open it.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: It lies Madam, on your Father's Table—I'll run and fetch it immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Now we shall succeed, and every thing will be right again.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Madam, 'tis all too late—Somebody's coming up.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Ha! 'Tis Don Philip! Assist me Wit now, or never—Keep close your VEIL Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: What do I see, Leonora here.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Seeing this Lady in your Apartment Sir, I came to keep her Company till you cou'd come according to your Assignation.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Say rather Madam, that you came to meet Sir Charles Winlove—That this Lady is the Confederate of your Falshood, and that you have mistaken this Apartment for another.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: How Don Philip! I never saw such Assu∣rance in my Life.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Madam, I find my Suspicions are not so groundless as I just now believ'd 'em to be—But you shall see my good Nature is not to be Im∣pos'd upon.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: So! This is excellently fine indeed—First to bring strange Ladies to my Father's House, and then to turn the Fault upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Why Madam, can you deny that this Lady came here with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Yes Sir, I can—You know that she did not.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Nor did not you come here to meet the English Cavalier?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I won't Satisfy you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Sir, What have you done? I expected Sir Charles here, and instead of that, you are come and have Incens'd the Governour's Daughter to my Ruin.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Ha! Then I have been too rash indeed—I find now that this is the Lady I look'd for, and Jealousy has brought Leonora hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: So! His Countenance tells me he begins to soften to my Wish—I see her Stratagem has took.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: What shall I say to her? Madam, I find already I have been in an Error in my Suspi∣cions, but not in being false my self.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: So! Now you see your Assurance won't take, you'd endeavour to conceal your Falshood.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Madam, I can immediately clear my self of that—For to Satisfy you who this Lady is—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Oh Sir, I am not so passionately in Love, as to desire Satisfaction.
SP.STAGE: Enter Flora thro' the other Door.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Madam, I cou'd not find the Key before or—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Hist Flora, no more

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: I find I shall do Mischief if I talk.—Madam, your Father's coming with another Ca∣valier.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Prithee Leonora, hear me justify my self.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: No, I'll relate it all to my Lord, and as I never lov'd you, shall be glad of this Opportu∣nity to be rid of you—Excellently come off.
SP.STAGE: Enter Lorenzo, Sir Charles, and Aspin.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Ha! What's the matter Daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: My Father, and the English Cavalier! I am certainly betray'd again.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: His Daughter! I am strangely deceiv'd then—For I am sure this is the Lady that was taken with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Speak Leonora.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Your Lordship shou'd ask that Gentleman, who makes private Assignations, and brings strange Ladies to your House.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: How! Don Philip.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Pardon me Sir Charles for impeaching you—But Egad all must out—This Lady is the Captive, and came here to see my Friend, who was to have met her by Stealth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: That Lady the Captive! Now wou'd they (tho' I see her in my presence) perswade me I am Blind, and change her to another Person.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Sir Charles, you seem still to remain in the Dark—Pray Madam UNVEIL—Now is it Fidelia or no.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Ha! I am Thunder-struck—Sure 'tis the fond Error of my Eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: What say you now Sir Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: And yet methinks I cannot be deceiv'd—Is it my Fidelia then?

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Oh Sir Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: It is, it is—The Musick of her Voice informs me now 'tis she—Oh my Fidelia, let me fly with Joy into thy Arms, and breathe my Soul upon thy Lips.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Long have I wish'd Sir Charles for such a happy meeting—But past Misfortunes wou'd be an unwelcome Theme—Your Love will recom∣pence 'em—Be Constant for the future, and 'tis all I ask.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: No Chance but Death shall ever part us more—Sure I am lost in Transport and Sur∣prize—Oh my Fidelia! Methinks I cou'd repeat thy Name, till distant Waters catch the charming Eccho, and when they rowl high in their mountain Waves, resound it to the Skies!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Nay, amongst all your Adventures I think I never saw you in such Raptures before.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Pardon me Friends if all my Senses are o'recome with Joy and Admiration.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: This is pleasant indeed Sir Charles—That you shou'd contrive to see the Lady, and yet not know she was here before.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: My Lord, Sir Charles is a Cavalier for the Ladies—And such ever esteem Secrecy as a Point of Honour—Therefore you must excuse him for his Reasons.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Ha! Now I begin to understand this Mystery—Fidelia has given me a hint of my In∣constancy—But I must conceal my Affairs with the other Lady from the Company.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Is the Riddle explain'd to your Satisfacti∣on Sir Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: It is my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: So, I see he has taken the hint—Well tho' I have lost my Lover, I shall preserve my Honour, that's one Comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Now I believe by the Joy of my Master, and the humour of this Company, that all is like to go well—If so, 'tis the first good Accident, that ever I knew a Woman the occasion of.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Now to add to the Pleasures you receive—Know I have this Morning had Notice from Madrid, that the Cavalier who was thought to have been kill'd, is perfectly recover'd of his Wounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: This is happy indeed—For methinks my Fidelia, I would not have the stain of Blood fully my Character, nor a melancholy Thought amidst the Joys of Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Sir Charles, you must grant me the Fa∣vour of Solemnizing your Marriage at my House, with these that are to be Coupled also.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Shall I then Madam, have the happi∣ness of a Reconciliation at last?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Aye Don Philip—For as this Affair has been carry'd on by Quarrels, I think it may Na∣turally end in Marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Now there is nothing wanting to com∣pleat our Blessing but a Reconciliation with my Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: That Madam I hope is in my Power to gain you; for know that the Lord Alonzo is now in my House.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: What! In Valencia my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Yes Madam—But here he comes! Retire at a Distance, and you shall see me break this Affair to him.
SP.STAGE: [The Company retire to the Back-part of the Stage.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: So my Lord! I have seen Sir Charles Winlove according to my Promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Well, and what does he say? How does he behave himself?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: As I expected my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: As you expected! Humph! That is I suppose you have told him the News of the Cavalier's Recovery, and now he very peremp∣torily bids Defiance, and intends to March off with my Daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Still you won't Comprehend me.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Lord, I tell you, I do comprehend you! Don't I know that he is a very bloody Mind∣ed Fellow? Has he not Stole away my Daugh∣ter, and for ought I know riffled her of all?—And this I can't Comprehend Forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: You won't hear me—

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Nay, I tell you, I do hear you—But I'll not be so impos'd upon I am resolv'd—A Pen and Ink there! Since the Law won't do me Justice, I'll Write the Dog a Challenge, and you shall be the Bearer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: A very pretty Office for a Magistrate indeed! But suppose he shou'd submit to your own Terms?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Why let him—My Terms are Sword and Pistol, tell him so! Odd, tho' I am an old Fellow, I can still take a Breathing upon Oc∣casion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Nay, since I can't satisfy you my Self, I have another Card to play—Come forward there.
SP.STAGE: [The Company Approach, Sir Charles Winlove, and Fidelia Kneel.
SP.P: Now will you be brought to Reason?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Ha! What's the meaning of all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Speak to him Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: My Lord, consider I am your Daugh∣ter, and forgive my Weakness.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Humph!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: My Lord, we only want your Bles∣sing to Compleat our Happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: My Blessing! Why I was talking of cutting your Throat you Dog—And now instead of Tilting, you ask me for my Bles∣sing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Sir Charles has had an Honourable Af∣fection for your Daughter, and he only wants your Consent to make her his Wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Make her his Wife say you! Is he in Earnest?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: My Lord, I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Nay, then take her with all my Heart—Rise Daughter, I forgive you, and Heaven Bless you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Now, 'tis as it shou'd be.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Aye and so it is—Since he makes her his Wife, I am very well satisfied!—Buss me Daughter, and you too Sir Charles, and now we are all Friends again—But I did intend to send you a Challenge Faith—However instead of pushing at me in a Duel, turn your Weapon upon my Daughter, and make me a Grand-Father, d'ye hear!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Why, that's well said!—But won't you take Notice of the rest of the Company?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Aye, with all my Heart—Who are they?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: This is my Daughter, and this my Son-in-Law that is to be.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Is this your Daughter? Faith she's very pretty!—Madam, by your Leave [Salutes her] Well, since we are all Reconcil'd old Friend, lets have an Entertainment suitable to this Oc∣casion.
SP.STAGE: [A Dance, after which they come forward.]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: My Lord, I thank you for the Favours that I here Receive—And now my Fidelia, I begin to be Satisfy'd, that true Happiness only Consists in a Retire∣ment from the Follies of the World—And your Conduct has so far Converted me from a loose Opinion of your Sex, that I shall ever think,

Q.L: No Joys on Earth, can with Chaste Love compare,
And beyond Riches, prize a Vertuous Fair.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE Spoken by Miss Lindar.
DIV1.L: WELL! As I'm Champion for young Bayes's Play,
Take care good People of the Words you say!
For if I like 'em not, I shall Abuse you!
And were I big enough—I wou'd so use you!
What have I said? You laugh at my Behaviour,
And think me yet too Young to Ask a Favour,
Faith now I'm cool again, I think so too!
What did our Author then intend to do?
I must Confess, I'm angry at th' Abuse—
To send me here, to make his Play's excuse!
Why, what a piece of Folly has he shown?
He shou'd consider I'm not yet full Grown!
If I had reach'd my Teens, or something nigh,
I shou'd have been well pleas'd my Strength to try!
How'ere Gallants, I yet believe—A Kiss
Might bribe the Boldest—Surely none wou'd Hiss!
Nay, as it is, you each must stand my Friend,
If Youth's a Fault, I ev'ry Day shall Mend;
For here you know, like Gard'ner's forc'd endeavours,
We sprout apace! and soon may grant you Favours—
And when I'm Ripe, I find it in my Nature
To be a very easy loving Creature!
I wou'd do much to gain your future Graces—
Come! Let me see a Smile upon your Faces!
If you once think to put on Frowns to Fright me,
I'll be reveng'd, and Dye a Maid to spite ye.

DIV1.HEAD: ERRATA.
DIV1.P: Page 5, line ult. for her, read a. Page 35, line 17, for got into, read caught in.
